author: @dainikbhaskar
title: सेवा केंद्र में नुक्कड़ नाटक कर नशे के बारे किया जागरूक
text:
Hindi NewsLocalPunjabAmritsar- Street Play Was Organized In The Service Center To Create Awareness About Drug Addiction
सेवा केंद्र में नुक्कड़ नाटक कर नशे के बारे किया जागरूक
अमृतसर1 घंटे पहले
- कॉपी लिंक
अमृतसर | डीसी साक्षी साहनी के निर्देश में चलाए जा रहे ‘युद्ध नशे विरुद्ध’ अभियान के तहत खालसा कॉलेज की थियेटर टीम ने सेवा केंद्र में नुक्कड़ नाटक का आयोजन कर लोगों को नशे से बर्बादी के बारे जागरूक किया। डीसी ने कहा कि सरकार ने नशे के खिलाफ मुहिम शुरू
.

लॉगिन करें

author: financialcontent.com
title: Netflix Sponsors Bigga$tate And Sip The Kid On Their Squid Games #181 Music Tour. | FinancialContent Business Page
text:
The tour flyer was inspired by Squid Games The Challenge's website for finding contestants that aired in the popular Netflix show and it features original promotional material used for Sip The Kid's debut on Netflix and Bigga$tate's Cartoon avatar adds a fun spin alongside all the sponsors and affiliates that helped make the tour possible, including Afroman will be performing alongside Bigga$tate and Sip The Kid will host all the events to remind everyone of Netflix as promotion. The partnership between Netflix, Squid Games, Deandre Smith also known as Sip The Kid and Jonathan Henderson also known as Bigga$tate comes as no surprise as both Creators of the Tour, have already been seen on Netflix for 2 Movies and Shows, especially Sip The Kid who has just recently aired in the "Squid Games The Challenge" that just had their season Finale Dec 7th. Bigga$tate will be the first musician in history to Curate and pitch a tour successfully to Netflix. From Squid Games The Experience to Podcasts and even Livestreaming to express how they feel after being on "Squid Games The Challenge." All participants on the popular Netflix show was given free reign to promote alongside Netflix any way they could come up with. But no one would have ever guessed that from a one time brainstorm between Sip The Kid and Bigga$tate, would come an idea that helped them both make history by creating a music tour around the most popular show on Netflix that has never added any music tours themed around Squid Games before.
With this being the first one ever, it has inspired St. Louis Cardinals to sponsor content and even attracted Afroman to perform alongside Bigga$tate who will add many events from his hometown in Chicago to bring back commercial opportunities to a city that brought even more opportunities to him. And ironically Sip The Kid's first movie role was in Chicago so they decided to add many dates from that city and Iowa, considering Sip The Kid's Hometown as well. There was no better addition for the Iowa roster part of the Tour than Tone Da Boss who has brought many events and joy to Iowa as a music label owner who is loved by his city enough to have a holiday given to him by the mayor.
The Creators of the tour decided to affiliate their Squid Games #181 Tour with this Win Tour. Bigga$tate will be performing his song with popular rapper Bobby Shmurda and Darrion Da Don another Chicago artist recruited by Bigga$tate for the tour from personally knowing how hard it is to change the narrative of being labeled a dangerous rapper just by where you're from or who you know, like he is often associated with Fbg Duck due to his relative but Darrion Da Don aims to leave a legacy for his daughter instead, by doing things like this with Netflix that helps the world see him for his craft and not just for the politics of his city. The Tour starts December 29th 2023.
 Squid Games #181 Music Tour
Contact Person: Jonathan Henderson
Email: Send Email
Country: United States
Website: https://www.instagram.com/reel/C1VIdIFOwW4/?igsh=MTVvdmZvYThqbDBsdQ==

author: Tania Galván
title: Irina Baeva sorprende a Gabriel Soto en su cumpleaños
text:
Por Tania Galván - Miami abril 18, 2024 4:57 pm EDT Después de disfrutar al máximo del íntimo festejo que le preparó a Gabriel Soto por su cumpleaños número 49, Irina Baeva le dedicó en redes una cariñosa felicitación y compartió algunas imágenes de cómo sorprendió a su prometido . La actriz usó su cuenta de Instagram para compartir con sus más de 3.9 millones de seguidores un mensaje para el cumpleañero quien, a tenor de las imágenes, se conmovió con la sorpresa que le preparó.
©@gabrielsoto
La romántica felicitación de su prometida Junto a un álbum de fotos donde vemos a Gabriel sosteniendo su pastel de cumpleaños, Irina Baeva escribió: “Amor mío Gabriel que seas siempre el más feliz y que el universo te de vuelva todo lo bello y maravilloso que tú le regalas al mundo. Te amo”. En esta publicación también incluyó algunos videos de su prometido en momentos divertidos. En sus historias, la actriz compartió un clip del momento exacto en el que Gabriel sopló las velitas de su pastel.
Más romántica que nunca, Irina le escribió: “¡Feliz cumpleaños al amor de mi vida!, la más afortunada de ser parte de tu camino”. En las imágenes vemos cómo Gabriel Soto pide su deseo antes de soplar las velitas, con Las Mañanitas, interpretadas por Ángela Aguilar , de fondo. La actriz captó el lindo momento donde se ve al festejado, ilusionado, leyendo la frase que adornaba su pastel: “Más viejo, sabio y caliente que nunca”.
©@irinabaeva
MÁS NOTAS RELACIONADAS:
Gabriel Soto revela cómo la pérdida de su madre le ha afectado en sus relaciones
Gabriel Soto reacciona a las declaraciones de Geraldine Bazán en La Casa de los Famosos
Irina resaltó en el cumpleaños de Gabriel el espíritu libre y positivo del actor. Para muestra, compartió un clip en sus historias, de una de sus tantas visitas al mar donde lo vemos cantando el tema Three Little Birds de Bob Marley , mientras disfrutaban de una jornada en altamar: “Siempre así”, escribió Baeva. En otro video vemos a Gabriel lanzarse al mar de la manera más intrépida: “Y así”, añadió la actriz.
©@irinabaeva
Un cumpleaños trabajando Por su parte, el actor reveló que pasó su cumpleaños trabajando con el productor de teatro Gerardo Quiroz: “Festejo 40, sí, 40 más 9. Quiero agradecerles a todos sus muestras de cariño, sus mensajes, de verdad, me siento tan bendecido y tan agradecido de tener a tanta gente que me quiere y que me felicita, gracias, los quiero, estoy tratando de contestarles a todos, pero ahorita tengo un ensayo y voy a estar toda la tarde en el teatro”, explicó el actor quien próximamente protagonizará la puesta en escena El precio de la fama .
Vídeo Relacionado: Patrick Schwarzenegger rinde homenaje a Chance Perdomo Loading the player... Suscríbete a nuestra newsletter. Se el primero en conocer las noticias sobre tus celebridades y miembros de la realeza favoritos y descubre las últimas tendencias en moda y belleza. Más sobre

author: Redacción digital Noticias Cuatro
title: John Mark, el personaje clave de Putin que controla la mayor red de bulos
text: De ser un sheriff en Florida a publicar bulos desde Moscú: así es John Mark, el personaje clave de Putin John Mark fue acusado por uso excesivo de fuerza, acoso sexual y hasta 21 delitos graves de extorsión Su última mentira ha sido la de acusar a Tim Walz, mano derecha de Kamala Harris, de agresión sexual Elecciones en Estados Unidos: Donald Trump siembra la duda del fraude aunque las encuestas le favorecen John Mark Dougan era un simple sheriff de Palm Beach (Florida) con un pasado en la Marina de Estados Unidos. Ahora, desde una cómoda oficina de Moscú, dirige una de las redes de noticias falsas más importantes del mundo. Entre sus objetivos está interferir en la guerra de Ucrania o influir en las próximas elecciones presidenciales de Estados Unidos que, por ahora, dan una [ventaja al candidato republicano Donald Trump.](https://www.cuatro.com/noticias/internacional/20241023/elecciones-estados-unidos-factores-favorecen-donald-trump-kamala-harris_18_013805425.html) Dougan usa las redes sociales para publicar mentiras, unos bulos que corren como la pólvora. Este hombre tiene una acreditada red de fake news financiada por el Kremlin, así lo ha desvelado una investigación de [‘The Washington Post’. ](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/10/23/dougan-russian-disinformation-harris/) MÁS John Mark Dougan, de sheriff a creador de bulos en Moscú Todo empezó en 2016, cuando huyó de la Justicia estadounidense tras fracasar en una cruzada personal contra su jefe. John Mark Dougan fue acusado por uso excesivo de fuerza, acoso sexual y hasta 21 delitos graves de extorsión. Rusia le dio asilo y, desde entonces, se ha convertido en un personaje clave en el plan de Vladimir Putin, el presidente de Rusia. La investigación de este medio internacional -que han contado con más de 150 documentos- revela que ha recibido financiación del GRU, el servicio de inteligencia militar de Rusia. Su trabajo consiste en difundir bulos y exponer, según él, las bondades de Rusia a Occidente. Su última mentira, una de las más sonadas, ha sido la de acusar de agresión sexual a Tim Walz, la mano derecha de Kamala Harris. Este vídeo falso obtuvo casi cinco millones de visitas en la plataforma X. Una campaña de desinformación orquestada desde Rusia, aún sin saber por qué el Kremlin tiene tanto interés por el republicano. Trump ha logrado una ventaja de dos puntos con respecto a la candidata demócrata: 47% frente al 45% de la demócrata Kamala Harris. Síguenos en [nuestro canal de WhatsApp](https://www.cuatro.com/noticias/20240508/noticias-cuatro-canal-whatsapp_18_012410835.html) y conoce toda la actualidad al momento.

author: NICK WILLIAMS THE (SHAMOKIN) NEWS-ITEM
title: Meteor showers to remain visible through early August
text:
SELINSGROVE — In addition to both the Southern Delta Aquariids and Alpha Capricornids peaking Wednesday morning, the Perseids meteor shower were also active, allowing stargazers to see three astronomic events at once.
The best time to view the showers was in the early morning hours of Wednesday, July 30, between midnight and dawn, said Dr. Jennifer Carter, assistant professor of physics at Susquehanna University.

author: Tom Beattie
title: Lionel Messi helped Inter Miami break little-known MLS record | Football | Sport | Express.co.uk
text:
Lionel Messi wins record eighth Ballon d’Or after World Cup glory with Argentina
The impact of Lionel Messi's landmark move to Inter Miami has been laid bare after the club was awarded special dispensation for a third-kit by MLS. The Herons were handed the rare opportunity to produce a second change strip after sales of the team's jerseys topped the 100,000 mark.
Related articles
Cristiano Ronaldo shows his true colours with Lionel Messi ahead of last dance
Man Utd flop gets phone call from Messi to persuade him to sign for Miami The sensational arrival of the Argentine superstar stateside was accompanied with an unprecedented response by the American public during 2023. Not only was Messi afforded a reception often reserved for rock stars across the country during away trips with his new club, but jerseys bearing his name sold in staggering numbers.
Shirts adorned with the World Cup winner's iconic No.10 fast became a must-have fashion item in the US as fans and A-Listers alike turned out in their droves to watch the legendary forward. During his first few months at DRV PNK Stadium, household names including Kim Kardashian , Selena Gomez and LeBron James witnessed him in action.
Now, the incredible effects of 'Messi mania' are quickly becoming clear, with MLS having granted Inter Miami permissions to produce a special new strip for 2024. According to Footy Headlines , the kit will pay homage to NFL team the Miami Dolphins in terms of its colour scheme.
Inter Miami shirts have proven overwhelmingly popular with fans around the world (Image: Getty) This potential nod to the iconic two-time Super Bowl winners could well prove a crossover hit for the David Beckham -owned MLS franchise. Fellow MLS teams LAFC, LA Galaxy, Kansas City and Portland Timbers will also be afforded the privellege of having a third-kit next term.
The Dolphins famously play in turquoise, alongside orange and white piping - a stark departure from Vice City's usual pale pink strip. Still, a kit which pays more than a subtle tribute to another true Floridan sporting institution could have appeal both locally and internationally.
The achievement of selling in excess of 100,000 jerseys demonstrates the cultural impact of Messi's move to the US in the space of less than six months. In fact, sales of the Herons' famous pale-pink shirts set new records as they outstripped that of Tom Brady jerseys upon his switch tothe Tampa Bay Buccaneers in 2020.
Don't miss...
Barcelona squad's 2014 food requests resurface including Nutella sandwich [LATEST]
Inter Miami complete Luis Suarez signing as David Beckham speaks out on deal [LATEST]
Novak Djokovic’s record breaking 2023 snubbed as baseball star secures award [LATEST]
Become an Express Premium member Support fearless journalism Read The Daily Express online, advert free Get super-fast page loading Start 30-day
FREE trial
Moreover, Tor Southard, the senior director of Adidas' football section, also informed the New York Times that orders reached the 500,000 mark in the aftermath of Messi's announcement of his move to Miami in the summer. This figure is higher than that achieved by Manchester United , Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, and Arsenal in the same period.
On top of this, Miami shirts also struck a chord with consumers from a fashion perspective with Vogue Magazine including the jerseys among the top must-have items of the year. They acknowledged that the ongoing clamour to own jerseys bearing Messi's name demonstrates his unique star power.
Explaining their choice, Vogue said: "Immediately following the Messi announcement, the generic Inter Miami jersey, in an unexpected shade of un-Barbie pink, sold out, giving rise to a rich bootleg industry. Now, nearly five months later, the official Messi jersey, sporting his number 10, remains wait-listed in most sizes on the Adidas website."
Related articles Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo to face off in final chapter of rivalry Tottenham could sell Barcelona's 'Messi replacement' due to Chelsea U-turn Lionel Messi thinks Tottenham have ‘best in the world’ and their own Luis Suarez Lionel Messi's historic World Cup shirts sell for £6m but miss out on record Man Utd exit close as Arsenal want Inacio and Chelsea eye 'next Messi'

author: Amy Sherman | PolitiFact
title: Trump is likely able to vote in November election despite his felony
text: Politifact FL: Donald Trump is likely able to vote in November despite felony conviction The Pulitzer Prize-winning team seeks to present the true facts, unaffected by agenda or biases. Former President and presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump’s felony conviction in New York raised questions about what comes next. Trump can still [run for president](https://www.politifact.com/article/2023/mar/20/some-questions-and-answers-on-donald-trumps-possib/), but claims about his voting eligibility followed the May 30 verdict. "Trump can’t vote for himself in the November election," Florida state Sen. Jason Pizzo, D-Sunny Isles Beach, [wrote](https://x.com/senpizzo/status/1796290713493139524) on X after the verdict. "He can thank Florida Republicans for that." Pizzo’s X post received a corrective, crowdsourced community note detailing what legal experts have [previously told us](https://www.politifact.com/article/2024/may/23/ask-politifact-could-trump-lose-his-voting-rights/): Trump likely would not lose his voting rights. Many legal experts, including the [Campaign Legal Center](https://x.com/JMDiazJD/status/1796304483561164886), a nonprofit group that supports voting rights, said Trump’s ability to vote hinges on whether he is in prison on Election Day. Trump’s sentencing is [scheduled](https://www.politifact.com/article/2024/may/30/trump-guilty-NY-trial-can-he-still-run-for/) for July 11. Many [legal](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/potential-outcomes-trumps-hush-money-trial/story?id=110300120) [experts](https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/how-could-trumps-new-york-hush-money-trial-end) have expressed doubt that Trump will be sentenced to prison because the charge is a nonviolent, low-level felony and he has no previous convictions. "We are going to be appealing this scam," Trump said at a May 31 [press conference](https://www.politifact.com/article/2024/may/31/fact-check-trump-conviction-speech/) at Trump Tower in New York. It is widely expected that the appeal process will extend beyond Election Day. READ MORE: [Florida voting advocates are fighting to keep the voting rolls accurate](https://www.wlrn.org/government-politics/2024-04-01/florida-voting-advocates-are-fighting-to-keep-the-voting-rolls-accurate) When we contacted Pizzo for comment, he said Trump would not have the right to vote until all the terms of his sentence had been satisfied, citing Florida law. We found that Florida defers to other states’ laws when the conviction is in their jurisdiction. Pizzo also acknowledged that Trump can vote while appealing his conviction. "Sen. Pizzo's statement holds true for someone convicted of a felony in Florida or in federal court — but Trump was convicted in state court in New York," Blair Bowie, director of the Restore Your Vote program at the Campaign Legal Center, told PolitiFact. "Trump will not lose his right to vote in this case unless he is in prison on Election Day." Florida’s law about voting after a felony conviction [States](https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/promises/biden-promise-tracker/promise/1532/incentivize-states-restore-voting-rights-convicted/) pass laws about whether people convicted of felonies lose their voting rights and if so, how they can regain them. Trump lives in Florida. People convicted in Florida of most felonies lose their voting rights until they serve their entire sentence, including prison time, probation and paying fines, according to the [Florida Department of State](https://dos.fl.gov/elections/for-voters/voter-registration/constitutional-amendment-4felon-voting-rights/). (Murder and sexual offense felonies make people ineligible to vote unless the [State Clemency Board](https://www.fcor.state.fl.us/restoration.shtml) restores their rights.) However, Trump was convicted in New York. And [according to](https://dos.fl.gov/elections/for-voters/voter-registration/constitutional-amendment-4felon-voting-rights/) Florida’s Department of State, "a felony conviction in another state makes a person ineligible to vote in Florida only if the conviction would make the person ineligible to vote in the state where the person was convicted." [New York law passed a 2021 law](https://elections.ny.gov/voting-after-incarceration) that restores voting rights for people convicted of felonies upon their release from prison. People convicted of felonies don’t lose the right to vote unless they are in prison serving their sentences. And people whose prison sentences are stayed pending appeal do not lose their voting rights, Kathleen R. McGrath, a New York state Board of Elections spokesperson, told [PolitiFact](https://www.politifact.com/article/2024/may/23/ask-politifact-could-trump-lose-his-voting-rights/). After Trump is sentenced, it is highly likely his lawyers will file a motion to the appeals court asking that the sentence be stayed during the appeal. In 99% of cases involving white-collar defendants, that motion is granted, said Evan Gotlob, a former local and federal prosecutor. "Former President Trump would therefore need to be actually incarcerated during the time of the November election to lose his ability to vote," [said Neil Volz](https://www.politifact.com/article/2024/may/23/ask-politifact-could-trump-lose-his-voting-rights/), the deputy director of the Florida Rights Restoration Coalition, the group that advocated for Florida’s 2018 constitutional [amendment](https://dos.elections.myflorida.com/initiatives/initdetail.asp?account=64388&seqnum=1) restoring felon voting rights. University of Florida political science professor [Michael McDonald](https://x.com/ElectProject/status/1796290753183858693), an expert on disenfranchisement of people convicted of felonies, told PolitiFact, "Trump may, in fact, be removed from the voter rolls but it seems highly unlikely he will be removed by November." "The most reasonable scenario here is that Trump remains on the voter rolls," McDonald said. "He could be sentenced to prison, and he could be serving time by the time we get to November, I guess I can’t rule out that possibility, but it seems like a very remote possibility." In 2018, [Floridians voted](https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2019/nov/21/nikki-fried/2019-few-florida-felons-got-their-voting-rights-ba/) in favor of the amendment that restores the voting rights of people with felony convictions after those people complete the terms of their sentences. Previously, people with felony convictions had to seek to regain their voting rights through the state [clemency board](https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2019/nov/21/nikki-fried/2019-few-florida-felons-got-their-voting-rights-ba/). Florida state officials, including from the Department of State, have not responded to PolitiFact’s questions about Trump’s voting rights. Trump is a registered voter in Palm Beach County. Our ruling Pizzo said, "Trump can’t vote for himself in the November election." This is premature and against the odds. The Florida Department of State says a felony conviction in another state invalidates the right to vote in Florida only if "the conviction would make the person ineligible to vote in the state where the person was convicted." That means New York’s laws would apply to Trump. In that state, people convicted of felonies lose the right to vote only while incarcerated. Trump is scheduled to be sentenced July 11. Even if he receives prison time — which many legal experts said they think is unlikely — it would be stayed pending an appeal that is likely to extend beyond Election Day. Pizzo’s statement contains an element of truth because it cannot be ruled out that Trump would be incarcerated on Election Day and therefore unable to vote for himself. But the statement ignores critical facts that would give a different impression: Trump has said he will appeal his conviction. This would stay his sentence until the appeal is complete — widely expected to be after Election Day. We rate this statement Mostly False. Our Sources - PolitiFact, Q&A: [Can Trump run for president if indicted in Stormy Daniels case? What happens if he's arrested?](https://www.politifact.com/article/2023/mar/20/some-questions-and-answers-on-donald-trumps-possib/), March 20, 2024 - Sen. PolitiFact, [Biden’s promise related to restoring felons’ voting rights stalls](https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/promises/biden-promise-tracker/promise/1532/incentivize-states-restore-voting-rights-convicted/), Dec. 16, 2021 - PolitiFact, [Trump guilty in NY trial: Can he still run for president or vote as a convicted felon?](https://www.politifact.com/article/2024/may/30/trump-guilty-NY-trial-can-he-still-run-for/), May 30, 2024 - Maybe.](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/04/22/trump-trials-felon-right-vote/73381143007/)April 22, 2024 - NPR, [If convicted this year, Trump could lose the right to vote for himself](https://www.npr.org/2024/04/14/1240672009/trump-conviction-voting-rights), April 26, 2024 - ABC News, [What are the potential outcomes of Trump's hush money trial?](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/potential-outcomes-trumps-hush-money-trial/story?id=110300120)May 20, 2024 - National Conference of State Legislatures, [Restoration of Voting Rights for Felons](https://www.ncsl.org/elections-and-campaigns/felon-voting-rights), April 17, 2024 - News Service of Florida, [A lawsuit over Florida's felon voting restrictions has been dropped](https://www.wlrn.org/government-politics/2024-05-15/florida-lawsuit-felon-voting-restrictions-dropped), May 15, 2024 - PolitiFact, [Biden’s promise related to restoring felons’ voting rights stalls](https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/promises/biden-promise-tracker/promise/1532/incentivize-states-restore-voting-rights-convicted/), Dec. 16, 2021 - PolitiFact, [Biden's statement on Trump's 2020 mail voting is Half True](https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2022/jan/13/joe-biden/trump-has-spread-falsehoods-about-voting-mail-whil/), Jan. 13, 2022 - PolitiFact, [Can Donald Trump run for president if charged and convicted of removing official records?](https://www.politifact.com/article/2022/aug/09/can-donald-trump-run-president-if-convicted-removi/)Aug. 9, 2022 - PolitiFact, [Q&A: Can Trump run for president if indicted in Stormy Daniels case? author: DONALD W. MEYERS Yakima Herald-Republic
title: Granger man sentenced to 30 years in prison for 2017 Toppenish gang killing | Crime And Courts | yakimaherald.com
text: A 29-year-old Granger man has been sentenced to 30 years in prison for a 2017 Toppenish homicide. Originally charged with first-degree murder in Indian Country, assault with a dangerous weapon in Indian Country, and discharging and using a firearm in a crime of violence, Jaime Herrera, 29, pleaded guilty to the murder and assault charges in March. Herrera is accused of fatally [shooting Waylon Owens, 23, of Toppenish](https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/local/toppenish-death-ruled-homicide/article_e2d95b40-6cb1-11e7-b51a-6fd171755bd5.html) in the 200 block of South Elm Street in the early morning hours of July 19, 2017. Herrera, at the time a Sureño gang member, pulled up to Owens and another man, accused them of being gang traitors, and shot Owens with an AR-15 assault rifle, according to court documents. The federal government took jurisdiction of the case because Owens was a Yakama Nation citizen, the other man was a citizen of the Nez Perce and the crime occurred within the Yakama Nation’s reservation. Herrera’s sentence, handed down Tuesday in U.S. District Court in Yakima, will run consecutively to his 20-year sentence in Yakima County Superior Court for the [2019 killing of Joe Albert Fuller](https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/local/crime_and_courts/three-sentenced-in-2019-killing-of-granger-man-on-cherry-hill-road/article_7b4b3c85-f2a3-5430-9523-6b727f3be0b1.html). Federal prosecutors recommended the 30-year sentence to run concurrently with his 20-year sentence in state court. Prosecutors noted that Herrera killed Fuller after killing Owens, “ruining multiple lives in the Yakima Valley.” “Should (Herrera) fully serve both sentences he will exit the custody of the (federal) Bureau of Prisons and the Washington State Department of Corrections as an old man, presumably physically incapable from continuing to commit acts of violence and socially disconnected from the gang and drug lifestyle that motivated his senseless behavior,” Assistant U.S. Attorneys Earl Hicks and Michael Ellis wrote in a sentencing memo. Lorinda Meyer Youngcourt, Herrera’s attorney, said Herrera accepted full responsibility for the crime and recommended Judge Mary K. Dimke follow the sentencing recommendation for 30 years running consecutively with the state sentence. She said Herrera faced “overwhelming obstacles to healthy development” growing up, including physical abuse, neglect, poverty, gang activity and drug sales. Herrera was also addicted to drugs and, being raised by gang members, he followed in their footsteps, Youngcourt said. She said Herrera dropped out of his gang in 2023, which puts him at risk of retaliation while incarcerated. Herrera’s father, Marcos Cruz Herrera Jr., was also convicted in Fuller’s death. But prosecutors said that Herrera’s upbringing was not an excuse for his crimes. “No one forced the defendant to kill; the defendant made his own terrible choices,” the prosecution’s sentencing memo said. “As noted by the defendant, he had an opportunity to get away and change his life while living in Spokane. The defendant chose not to, and instead took two lives and ruined countless others.”
